did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library
did.unittitle:
Papers Pertaining to Middle East Ventures of the Mobil Oil Corporation,
1951-1960
did.physdesc: This collection consists of 25,000 items (50 Hollinger boxes, ca. 28 linear shelf feet).

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
See the
University of Virginia Library’s use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Papers Pertaining to Middle East Ventures of the Mobil Oil Corporation, Accession #11224, Special Collections Dept., University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These papers were loaned to the University of Virginia Library by the Mobil Oil Corporation, Fairfax, Virginia, on March 11, 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of ca. 25,000 items, ca. 1951-1960, the papers of Mobil Oil Corporation and its Middle East petroleum ventures, filed under the headings of personnel, organization, conventions, supplies, pipelines, legal matters, prices, production, agreements, finances, meetings, office, agreements, reports, and government. The folders have an additional subheading depending on the name of the oil company involved.

These papers cover the period of the greatest expansion of oil companies and their influence in the Middle East before countries like Iraq and Iran nationalized their oil industries. Topics mentioned in the papers include: the Suez Canal Crisis in 1956, which closed the canal for four months and drastically affected some oil exports; the purchase of Safaniya crude oil & the Ras Tanura Refinery , and other crude oil under the heading agreements ; Under the heading of conventions and pipelines, there is a file on Tapline , the TransArabian Pipeline Company, which opened in December 1950 as the world's largest crude oil pipeline providing an outlet on the Mediterranean Sea for crude oil from ARAMCO's producing fields destined for Europe.

In 1933, the key oil concession in Saudi Arabia was assigned to California Arabian Standard Oil Company, which rose to international prominence during World War II when the U.S. government encouraged rapid development and full production for the war effort. The name of the company was changed in 1944 to Arabian American Oil Company or ARAMCO and by 1947 the Texas Company, Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, and Socony Vacuum Oil Company had all become partners in the Middle East venture, making ARAMCO the world's most important oil cartel.

Other oil companies represented in this collection include the British Petroleum Company , registered in 1909 as the Anglo-Persian Oil Company, Ltd., renamed the Anglo- Iranian Oil Company, Ltd., in 1935 and becoming the British Petroleum Company Limited in 1954, formed to take over and finance an oil-field concession in Iran ; the Iranian Oil Participants, Ltd. , a consortium of fourteen oil companies producing oil in Iran ; the Iraq Petroleum Company, Ltd. , a consortium of oil companies in Iraq ; and Mobil Oil .

The origins of Mobil Oil Corporation date to the 19th century. According to the Encyclopedia Britannica, "One predecessor, Vacuum Oil Company, was founded in 1866 and, after 1882, became part of the Standard Oil Trust. Another predecessor was Standard Oil Company of New York (Socony), established by the trust in 1882. Both companies became independent in 1911 when the U.S. Supreme Court dissolved the Standard Oil combine, but the two merged in 1931 to form Socony-Vacuum Corporation. The name was changed in 1934 to Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., in 1955 to Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., and then in 1966 to Mobil Oil Corporation."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of ca. 25,000 items (50 Hollinger boxes, ca. 28 linear shelf feet), ca. 1951-1960, the papers of Mobil Oil Corporation and its Middle East petroleum ventures, filed under the headings of personnel, organization, conventions, supplies, pipelines, legal matters, prices, production, agreements, finances, meetings, office, agreements, reports, and government. The folders have an additional subheading depending on the name of the oil company involved.
